note: A recommended review article on clinical "expert" knowledge is Dawes (2001).
title: where his beautiful summary pieces that fed me for the last four years are compiled—not being an academic, he gets straight to the point
for a selection of technical papers

container-title: focuses on game theory. General review essays and comprehensive books in cognitive science: Newell and Simon
title: More general psychology of decision presentations: Klein (1998) proposes an alternative model of intuition. See Cialdini (2001) for social manipulation. A more specialized work, Camerer
Fodor
Eysenck and Keane
Lakoff and Johnson
The MIT Encyclopedia of Cognitive Science has review articles by main thinkers

note: and Burnham (1997, 2003). Very readable: Burnham and Phelan
title: Evolutionary theory and domains of adaptation: See the original Wilson
Kreps and Davies
The compilation of Robert Trivers's work is in Trivers
The Political Brain: A Recent Brain-imaging Study Shows That Our Political Predilections Are a Product of Unconscious Confirmation Bias

note: Carter (1999, 2002), Conlan (1999), the very readable Lewis, Amini, and Lannon (2000), and Goleman (1995). See Glimcher (2002) for probability and the brain. For the emotional brain, the three books by Damasio (1994, 2000, 2003), in addition to LeDoux (1998) and the more detailed LeDoux (2002), are the classics. See also the shorter Evans (2002). For the role of vision in aesthetics, but also in interpretation, Zeki (1999). NOTES 3 1 7
title: Neurobiology of decision making: For a general understanding of our knowledge about the brain's architecture: Gazzaniga et al
Gazzaniga (2005) provides literary summaries of some of the topics. More popular: Carter
Also recommended: Ratey (2001
Ramachandran and Blakeslee

note: A general textbook on memory (in empirical psychology) isBaddeley (1997).
title: is a review work of the mem­ ory biases with links to the hindsight effects

container-title: For an illustration of the aggressiveness of groups
title: Intellectual colonies and social life: See the account in Collins (1998) of the "lineages" of philosophers (although I don't think he was aware enough of the Casanova problem to take into account the bias making the works of solo philosophers less likely to sur­ vive

Asymmetry: Prospect theory (Kahneman and Tversky [1979] and Tversky and Kahne­ man [1992]) accounts for the asymmetry between bad and good random events, but it also shows that the negative domain is convex while the positive domain is con

note: S&P 500: See Rosenzweig (2006). The long tail: Anderson (2006).
title: Wars: War is concentrated in an Extremistan manner: Lewis Fry Richardson noted last century the uneveness in the distribution of casualties
Modern wars: Arkush and Allen

In the study of the Maori, the pattern of fighting with clubs was sustainable for many centuries—modern tools cause 20,000 to 50,000 deaths a year. We are simply not made for technical warfare. For an anecdotal and causative account of the history of a war, see Ferguson
For the effect of the Internet on schools, see Han et al
For information cascades in eco­ nomics
See also Surowiecki

note: propose a market-based solution to the problem of al-
title: see arbitrary and random success by oth­ ers as no different from pollution, which necessitates the enactment of a tax. De Vany, Taleb, and Spitznagel
Furthermore, we sometimes converge very slowly to the Gaussian. For preasymptotics and scalability, Mandelbrot and Taleb (2007a
For the problem of working outside asymptotes, Taleb
Aureas mediocritas: historical perspective, in Naya and Pouey-Mounou (2005) aptly called Éloge de la médiocrité
Catastrophes: Posner
Concentration and modem economic life: Zajdenweber
Choices of society structure and compressed outcomes: The classical paper is Rawls

contradict the notion of the desirability of Rawl's veil (though by experiment). People prefer maximum average income subjected to a floor constraint on some form of equality for the poor, inequality for the rich type of environment
